description: From Middle English Maudelen, a dialectal form of Mary Magdalene (typically depicted weeping), from Old French Madelaine, from Late Latin Magdalena.

adjectives.description: maudlin (comparative more maudlin, superlative most maudlin)

entries.meaning: Affectionate or sentimental in an effusive, tearful, or foolish manner, especially because of drunkenness. [from 17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: mushy, sappy, schmaltzy, soupy, slushy; see also Thesaurus:drunk

entries.meaning: Extravagantly or excessively sentimental; mawkish, self-pitying. [from 17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: emotional, overwrought, soppy, larmoyant, mournful, plaintful, teary, weepy; see also Thesaurus:sad

entries.meaning: (obsolete, Christianity) The Magdalene; Mary Magdalene. [14th–16th c.]
examples: for alle they worſchipden hir ſouereynly / as worthy was / but ſpecially Mawdelayne / that wolde neuere departe fro hir.

entries.meaning: (historical) Either of two aromatic plants, costmary or sweet yarrow. [from 15th c.]
examples: Common Maudlin have somewhat long and narrow leaves, snipped about the edges.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A Magdalene house; a brothel. [17th c.]
